title: At the end of a letter, or email, why do people write, 'please respond by reply'? Why does the phrase feel so wrong? - Quora

response.answer_text: Without context, it is wrong. With the right context, it makes sense. The wrong version is because in standard usage, a reply is a particular type of response. It’s a bit redundant. It could make bit of sense in that you could respond by deleting the email or shredding the letter. That’s not the usual intent however. Within an email context, it makes complete sense. A recipient can reply to an email using two methods: “reply” and “reply all”. “reply” sends the response back only to the sender of the email. “reply all” sends the response back to the sender and everyone who was sent the original message. New users of email often respond to emails using “reply all.” In many situations, this just clutters up the inbox of everyone else on the email thread. For example, if there is going to be a banquet for 100 people, I might send out and email to the 100 people asking whether they want chicken or fish. An inexperienced email user will hit “reply all” and respond with “chicken” or “fish”. The result is that 100 people will now know that the responder wants chicken or fish. If this is done by all 100 recipients, every recipient now has 99 useless emails that they need to deal with. “Please respond by reply” is a polite way of saying “Please do not use reply all and spam everybody with your response.” See also Email storm - Wikipedia and the bedlam incident at Microsoft: Me Too!

I’ve never seen it, but it seems wrong because it expresses the same request twice within three words. re·spond /rəˈspänd/ Learn to pronounce verb 1.say something in reply. (italics added)re·ply /rəˈplī/ Learn to pronounce verb 1.say something in response (italics added)YCMTSU, folks. The first two dictionary searches turned up these words as the prime definition of one another. They’re two-syllable words from the third grade or something. To try to sound formalistic by using both sounds odd to this Floridian-Californian English literature major. “Respond by reply” isn’t idiomatic that I’ve ever heard. Perhaps the OP isn’t referring to U.S. English. If it’s idiomatic somewhere else in the English-speaking world, that’s why people keep doing it. Idioms got their name because they don’t make literal sense but are in common use anyway and are accepted for their common, if illogical, understood meaning.

It seems to me that no one here has picked up the meaning as I’ve understood it to be. Often, “respond by reply” is added to an email that contains questions or the need for decision to be taken by the recipient. If you receive an email with this wording, it indicates that you should only reply to the email once you are capable of answering to the questions asked. It could mean “Do not send me more of your nonsense, thoughts or excuses until you are able to give me a clear answer on my queries”. It is used in the same way when written “please attach by reply” meaning “Do not waste my time on yet another email saying that you are ‘working on it’. Answer only once the agreement is signed by yourself and attached to the email for me to see”.

This is one of those peculiar pseudo-English phrases popularized by ESL speakers and picked up by other ESL speakers and blasted all over Creation. It makes native English speakers scratch their heads and think, “Wtf? How else would I respond? By carrier pigeon? Telepathy? Smoke signals?” The originator of the message might just as well add a random phrase such as, “Please read this message” or “Please breathe now.” The phrase feels wrong because it’s unnecessary nonsense. Simple as that.

On the surface, it doesn't make sense, but in the context of an e-mail, it could be that the writer wants the person to respond with the "Reply" button rather than send a new e-mail. Helps to keep track of correspondence if you have a reliable e-mail chain.
